thread.title: The finals mistake Cats won’t make again

title: The finals mistake Cats won’t make again
text:
Geelong coach Chris Scott opens up on the side’s embarrassing 2016 finals loss to Sydney March 2, 2017 5:51pm @bjwaterworth Source: FOX SPORTS GEELONG coach Chris Scott is adamant there’s no sense of urgency for his club to win a premiership this season, despite the Cats’ list demographic and recent substandard finals record. 
The Cats enter the 2017 season sporting the fourth-oldest list in the competition, with 56 per cent of the list aged between 24 and 28. 
Most of the 22 players in that age bracket have been part of Geelong’s recent finals campaigns, which have yielded just two wins from eight attempts — including last year’s post-siren victory over Hawthorn. 
In a wideranging interview with Fox Sports News, Scott said his list was in a “better position” now to challenge than it had been for the past five to six seasons. 
But the 2011 premiership coach said he felt no added pressure for Geelong to walk away with the premiership cup in 2017. 
“We feel like we’re in a pretty good position now, but it’s not a make or break year — if that’s even such a thing,” Scott told AFL Tonight. 
“We’ll do our very best this year, but no matter what happens — win, lose or draw — we’ll push really hard to have an even better year this year.” 
Scott said he was confident that Cats players in the ‘prime’ age group, such as Patrick Dangerfield (27-years-old), Joel Selwood (29), Tom Hawkins (29), Daniel Menzel (26) and Cameron Guthrie (25), still has ample improvement left in them, hence why he doesn’t feel any burden for immediate success. 
“Those guys are contracted out for a long time, so we have a bit of faith that they have a lot of good football in front of them,” Scott said. 
“The point is certainly valid in that if we wait until those guys are 32 to really hit our straps … we shouldn’t expect the same sort of contribution from them.” Patrick Dangerfield after the final siren. Picture: Wayne Ludbey. Source: News Corp Australia 
THE SUDDEN, SHOCKING FINALS EXIT 
SCOTT’S Cats had a tremendous home and away campaign last season, finishing second on the ladder with a 17-5 record. 
However Geelong was bundled out of the finals series in embarrassing fashion, losing to a dominant Sydney outfit in a humiliating preliminary final loss. 
Cats skipper Joel Selwood admitted last month that his club “didn’t get it right” against the Swans, pointing to the Cats’ pre-match preparation and in-game set-up. 
Scott said all eight finalists headed into “uncharted territory” last year due to the debut of the pre-finals bye. The Cats were one of two teams who played just two games in four weeks, after they beat the Hawks in thrilling circumstances in the qualifying final. 
“Make no mistake, we still think that winning that first final in the first week of the finals was a good thing to do. But there was a lot of time off, at least from match practice, through that period,” Scott said. 
“On reflection, we would’ve trained a little bit differently. They’re not huge shifts, but the ability to simulate finals-pressure at training is very difficult. Maybe we should’ve tried a little bit harder to simulate that pressure.” 
Scott added that it was “completely illogical” to suggest the poor loss to the Swans would be the driving factor behind the Cats’ 2017 campaign. 
“If we had have won the premiership last season, I don’t think we would’ve been trying any less through this preseason — at least I hope now,” he said. 
THE HEAVY RELIANCE ON ‘DANGERWOOD’ 
A CONSTANT point of discussion last year was the chasm between Dangerfield and Selwood and the rest of the Geelong midfield. 
Of the Cats’ on-ball brigade, Dangerfield and Selwood are the only two ‘elite’ players, according to Champion Data, with Guthrie, Mitch Duncan and Mark Blicavs the next best with ‘average’ ratings. 
Scott said the Cats would continue to have big expectations for ‘Dangerwood’, but insisted the club wanted its next batch to show improvement. 
“It’s an acknowledgment of how good those two are. If we can find another two or three who are approaching that level, we’ll have the best midfield of all time,” Scott said. 
“Having said that, we have worked pretty hard to develop a group of players who should be coming into their prime who can go some way to filling that gap. But if the option is to lessen your strength to strengthen the weak, I think that would be a poor way to go. 
“We’d like to get more from all our players. We don’t feel like we have anyone on the list that isn’t in a position to have a career-best year. 
“The 24 to 27-years-olds, those guys that are coming into their primes, we have a realistic expectation that they would play better this year.” An early onslaught set up Sydney’s victory. Source: AAP 
HOLD YOUR HORSES ON HARRY 
HARRY Taylor won a couple of All-Australian jumpers as a defender, but has been flagged as a potential full-time forward for this season. 
Asked if putting Taylor forward could turn into a case of ‘robbing Peter to pay Paul’, Scott said: “Absolute there is.” 
But Scott added that Taylor’s role for the year hadn’t been completely nailed down yet. 
“While he’s done some training there, it’s not a lay down misere that he’ll play there,” Scott said. 
“It’s just we feel it’ll add another string to our bow.” 
NO THIRD MAN UP, NO WORRIES 
THE scrapping of the third-man up will not influence Mark Blicavs’ output and Geelong’s stoppage tactics, according to Scott. 
The AFL in December outlawed the third man up tactic for the 2017 season, disallowing Blicavs — clearly the league’s No. 1 third-man up last year — and the Cats from utilising one of their best assets. 
But Scott said the new situation was not going to have a huge influence on both his side and Blicavs. 
“It was a case of if you can’t beat them, join them — and we had a unique player in Mark Blicavs who’s very athletic and very tall, so it was obvious to use him,” Scott said. 
“The big ruckman will probably have more influence, there’ll be an interesting debate as to the importance of the second ruckman ... and stoppages could be a bit more stable and less chaotic. 
“We have a view, yet to be tested, that maybe the dominant midfielders might profit from this.”
